input.content:
You are an agent trying to solve a web task based on the content of the page and
user instructions. You can interact with the page and explore, and send messages to the user. Each time you
submit an action it will be sent to the browser and you will receive a new page.

content.text:
# Instructions
Review the current state of the page and all other information to find the best
possible next action to accomplish your goal. Your answer will be interpreted
and executed by a program, make sure to follow the formatting instructions.

## Goal:

Create a new incident
 
 Concretely, you need to complete the following steps:
1. Navigate to the "Incidents" module of the "Service Desk" application.
2. Create a new incident with a value of "Lost connection to the wireless network" for field "Short description", a value of "Rick Berzle" for field "Caller", a value of "Closed before close notes were made mandatory" for field "Resolution notes", a value of "Hardware" for field "Category", a value of "INC0000030" for field "Number", a value of "" for field "Configuration item", a value of "Can't connect to wifi. Keep getting "unable to join network" message." for field "Description", a value of "3 - Low" for field "Urgency", a value of "false" for field "Knowledge", a value of "3 - Low" for field "Impact", a value of "Phone" for field "Channel", a value of "" for field "Caused by Change", and a value of "policy" for field "New laugh".

# Observation of current step:

## Currently open tabs:
Tab 0 (active tab):
    Title: Create INC0010059 | Incident | ServiceNow
    URL: https://dev226733.service-now.com/incident.do?sys_id=-1&sysparm_view=default

# History of interaction with the task:

## step 0

<think>
To navigate to the Incidents module, I need to open the All menu first.
</think>

<action>
click('79')
</action>

## step 1

<think>
The "All" menu is expanded. To access the Incidents module, click the "Incidents" link in the list.
</think>

<action>
click('346')
</action>

## step 2

<think>
To access the Service Desk application, I need to open the "More menus" dropdown in the primary navigation.
</think>

<action>
click('84')
</action>

## step 3

<think>
To create a new incident, I need to click the "New" button on the Incidents list.
</think>

<action>
click('a145')
</action>

## step 4

<think>
The "Short description" field is mandatory and visible, so I’ll populate it first with the specified value.
</think>

<action>
fill('a352', 'Lost connection to the wireless network')
</action>

## step 5

<think>
The form contains additional fields further down for Category, Configuration item, Description, etc., which aren’t currently visible. I need to scroll to reveal and interact with those fields next.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0, 600)
</action>

## step 6

<think>
The next step is to update the Caller field to "Rick Berzle". I'll populate the searchbox at bid 'a189' with that value.
</think>

<action>
fill('a189', 'Rick Berzle')
</action>

## step 7

<think>
The caller field is expanded but not yet selected. I will choose the "Rick Berzle rick.berzle@example.com" option.
</think>

<action>
click('a782')
</action>

## step 8

<think>
The remaining fields (Category, Configuration item, Description, Impact, Knowledge, Channel, Resolution notes, New laugh) are below the fold, so I will scroll further down to reveal them.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0, 800)
</action>

## step 9

<think>
The incident number field is auto-populated with INC0010058 but needs to be set to INC0000030. I will override the Number field at bid 'a176'.
</think>

<action>
fill('a176', 'INC0000030')
</action>

## step 10

<think>
The remaining fields (Category, Configuration item, Description, Impact, Knowledge, Channel, Resolution notes, New laugh) are not yet visible. I need to scroll further down to reveal them.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0, 1200)
</action>

## step 11

<think>
The Category field and other remaining fields are still out of view in this long form. I will scroll further down to reveal them so I can fill them in.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0, 2000)
</action>

## step 12

<think>
The remaining form fields (Category, Configuration item, Description, Impact, Knowledge, Channel, Resolution notes, New laugh) are not visible yet. I'll scroll further down to reveal them so I can fill them in.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0, 3000)
</action>

## step 13

<think>
The required fields like Category, Description, and others are not present in the Self Service view. I need to switch to the Default form view to expose these fields, using the "More options" menu on the form toolbar.
</think>

<action>
click('a81')
</action>

## step 14

<think>
The default form view is accessed via the "Additional actions" menu (the kebab icon), not the More options toggle. I'll click the additional actions menu to switch views.
</think>

<action>
click('a57')
</action>

## step 15

<think>
The Self Service view hides required fields. To reveal Category, Configuration item, Description, Impact, Knowledge, Channel, Resolution notes, and New laugh, I'll reload the form in the default view by removing the `sysparm_view=ess` parameter and setting `sysparm_view=default`.
</think>

<action>
goto('https://dev226733.service-now.com/incident.do?sys_id=-1&sysparm_view=default')
</action>

## step 16

<think>
The “Number” field is prepopulated with INC0010059 but needs to be set to INC0000030. I will override it by filling the Number textbox (bid 174).
</think>

<action>
fill('174', 'INC0000030')
</action>

## step 17

<think>
I need to enter the resolution notes and the custom “New laugh” field, which are on the Resolution Information tab. I’ll switch to that tab first.
</think>

<action>
click('575')
</action>

## step 18

<think>
The next required field to set is the Category. I'll select "Hardware" from the Category dropdown (bid 208).
</think>

<action>
select_option('208', 'Hardware')
</action>

## step 19

<think>
The Category is now set. The next field to populate is the Description. I will fill the Description textbox (bid '509') with the provided text.
</think>

<action>
fill('509', 'Can\'t connect to wifi. Keep getting "unable to join network" message.')
</action>

## step 20

<think>
I have filled in the Description. The next step is to set the Channel field to "Phone".
</think>

<action>
select_option('343', 'Phone')
</action>

## step 21

<think>
The Resolution Information tab is already active, so I can now fill the "Resolution notes" field (bid 917) with the required text.
</think>

<action>
fill('917', 'Closed before close notes were made mandatory')
</action>

## step 22

<think>
The custom “New laugh” field isn’t visible in the Resolution section; it may be further down. I will scroll a bit to reveal any additional fields.
</think>

<action>
scroll(0,200)
</action>

# Action space:
Note: This action set allows you to interact with your environment. Most of them
are python function executing playwright code. The primary way of referring to
elements in the page is through bid which are specified in your observations.
Remember to output your actions in <action></action> tags.


19 different types of actions are available.

noop(wait_ms: float = 1000)
    Description: Do nothing, and optionally wait for the given time (in milliseconds).
    Examples:
        noop()

        noop(500)

scroll(delta_x: float, delta_y: float)
    Description: Scroll horizontally and vertically. Amounts in pixels, positive for right or down scrolling, negative for left or up scrolling. Dispatches a wheel event.
    Examples:
        scroll(0, 200)

        scroll(-50.2, -100.5)

fill(bid: str, value: str)
    Description: Fill out a form field. It focuses the element and triggers an input event with the entered text. It works for <input>, <textarea> and [contenteditable] elements.
    Examples:
        fill('237', 'example value')

        fill('45', 'multi-line\nexample')

        fill('a12', 'example with "quotes"')

select_option(bid: str, options: str | list[str])
    Description: Select one or multiple options in a <select> element. You can specify option value or label to select. Multiple options can be selected.
    Examples:
        select_option('a48', 'blue')

        select_option('c48', ['red', 'green', 'blue'])

click(bid: str, button: Literal['left', 'middle', 'right'] = 'left', modifiers: list[typing.Literal['Alt', 'Control', 'ControlOrMeta', 'Meta', 'Shift']] = [])
    Description: Click an element.
    Examples:
        click('a51')

        click('b22', button='right')

        click('48', button='middle', modifiers=['Shift'])

dblclick(bid: str, button: Literal['left', 'middle', 'right'] = 'left', modifiers: list[typing.Literal['Alt', 'Control', 'ControlOrMeta', 'Meta', 'Shift']] = [])
    Description: Double click an element.
    Examples:
        dblclick('12')

        dblclick('ca42', button='right')

        dblclick('178', button='middle', modifiers=['Shift'])

hover(bid: str)
    Description: Hover over an element.
    Examples:
        hover('b8')

press(bid: str, key_comb: str)
    Description: Focus the matching element and press a combination of keys. It accepts the logical key names that are emitted in the keyboardEvent.key property of the keyboard events: Backquote, Minus, Equal, Backslash, Backspace, Tab, Delete, Escape, ArrowDown, End, Enter, Home, Insert, PageDown, PageUp, ArrowRight, ArrowUp, F1 - F12, Digit0 - Digit9, KeyA - KeyZ, etc. You can alternatively specify a single character you'd like to produce such as "a" or "#". Following modification shortcuts are also supported: Shift, Control, Alt, Meta, ShiftLeft, ControlOrMeta. ControlOrMeta resolves to Control on Windows and Linux and to Meta on macOS.
    Examples:
        press('88', 'Backspace')

        press('a26', 'ControlOrMeta+a')

        press('a61', 'Meta+Shift+t')

focus(bid: str)
    Description: Focus the matching element.
    Examples:
        focus('b455')

clear(bid: str)
    Description: Clear the input field.
    Examples:
        clear('996')

drag_and_drop(from_bid: str, to_bid: str)
    Description: Perform a drag & drop. Hover the element that will be dragged. Press left mouse button. Move mouse to the element that will receive the drop. Release left mouse button.
    Examples:
        drag_and_drop('56', '498')

tab_focus(index: int)
    Description: Bring tab to front (activate tab).
    Examples:
        tab_focus(2)

new_tab()
    Description: Open a new tab. It will become the active one.
    Examples:
        new_tab()

tab_close()
    Description: Close the current tab.
    Examples:
        tab_close()

go_back()
    Description: Navigate to the previous page in history.
    Examples:
        go_back()

go_forward()
    Description: Navigate to the next page in history.
    Examples:
        go_forward()

goto(url: str)
    Description: Navigate to a url.
    Examples:
        goto('http://www.example.com')

send_msg_to_user(text: str)
    Description: Sends a message to the user.
    Examples:
        send_msg_to_user('Based on the results of my search, the city was built in 1751.')

report_infeasible(reason: str)
    Description: Notifies the user that their instructions are infeasible.
    Examples:
        report_infeasible('I cannot follow these instructions because there is no email field in this form.')

Only a single action can be provided at once. Example:
fill('a12', 'example with "quotes"')

Think step by step. Put your thoughts in <think></think> tags.

# Concrete Example

Here is a concrete example of how to format your answer.
Make sure to follow the template with proper tags:

<think>
From previous action I tried to set the value of year to "2022",
using select_option, but it doesn't appear to be in the form. It may be a
dynamic dropdown, I will try using click with the bid "a324" and look at the
response from the page.
</think>

<action>
click('a324')
</action>
